All information used in the application is provided byUSGS. United States Geological Survey (USGS) is a scientific agency of the US government. USGS is an operational and research organisation, devoid of legal powers (it has no regulatory responsibility) that carries out research on objective facts relating to the environment. USGS manages the National Earthquake Information Center based in Golden (Colorado), an organization capable of identifying the location and magnitude of earthquakes around the world. The USGS motto is \"science for a changing world\" (science for a changing world).
What does the Richter scale measure?

The Richter index provides an objective assessment (magnitude) of the amount of energy released. 
 The Richter index is used to calculate the magnitude: it is not measured in degrees, but represents quantities corresponding to the amplitude of the seismic waves that an earthquake releases at its epicenter, elevated on a logarithmic basis. The zero on the scale is equivalent to a released energy of 105 Joules. The maximum recorded value was of magnitude 8.6 equivalent to the energy of 1018 J. 

<3.5: Usually not felt, but registered. 

3.5-5.4: Often felt, but rarely causes damage. 

under 6.0: At most slight damage to solid buildings. 

6.1-6.9: It can be destructive to areas within 100 km. 

7.0-7.9: Major earthquake. Causes serious damage over large areas. 

>=8: Major earthquake. It can cause serious damage over large areas of several hundred km.
What does the Mercalli scale measure?

The Mercalli scale is not a magnitude but a linear scale that evaluates the destructive effects of the earthquake in degrees, from a minimum of zero, equivalent to no effect on the population, things and buildings, to a maximum of 12 degrees, equivalent to total destruction. The Mercalli scale is therefore an empirical index, which, for example, cannot be calculated in a desert or uninhabited place, where there is nothing that can be destroy. It represents the intensity with which an earthquake occurs, based on its destructive capacity. 

I: Active 
II: Very light 
III: Light 
IV: Mediocre 
V: Strong 
VI: Very strong 
VII: Intense 
VIII: Ruinous 
IX: Disastrous 
X: Devastating 
XI: Catastrophic 
XII: Huge catastrophe

What is the difference between epicenter and hypocenter?

Hypocenter is the point, located deep inside the Earth, where the fault that generates the earthquake breaks. It is the point from which the seismic waves, responsible for a "seismic shock", start.\n Epicenter is the point of the earth\'s surface located on the vertical of the hypocenter. If a vertical line is drawn from the hypocenter, this would meet the surface in what we call the epicenter.

Drop to the ground in a clear spot away from buildings, trees and power lines.\n\nIf you are driving – pull over, stop and set your parking brake. Avoid overpasses, bridges, power lines, trees, signs, buildings, vehicles and other things that may fall on your car.

Drop down and take cover under a desk or table. Be prepared to hold on until the shaking stops. 

Stay inside until the shaking stops and it is safe to exit.

Stay away from stairs and lifts, usually stairs are the most fragile part of the building. The lift can get blocked.

Keep a first aid box at home. and make sure that everyone in the family knows where it is. 

Stay away from bookcases and other furniture that can fall on you. 

Stay away from windows and light fixtures.

Help injured or trapped people, but do not move seriously injured people unless they are in immediate danger of sustaining more injuries. Give first aid as appropriate.

If you are inside, exit the building and go to an open space far from any damage and other buildings.

Be aware of possible tsunamis if you live in a coastal area, and stay away from the beach. If a tsunami warning is issued, assume that dangerous waves are on the way. 

Go to a designated shelter if your home is no longer safe.

Put on long pants, a long-sleeved shirt, sturdy shoes and work gloves to protect yourself against broken objects.
